column4: Shibuya station's Hachiko Gate leads out towards the famous Shibuya Crossing and to the statue of Hachiko, the dog who waited patiently at this station for its deceased owner for many years.
This colorful theme cafe in Harajuku is located on the 4th floor of the YM Square building, one block North of the Meijijingu-Mae metro station.

Yoyogi Park is one of the largest parks in central Tokyo and is located next to Harajuku Station and Meiji Shrine. It is a place where joggers, cyclists, music fans and picnickers gather on sunny days. It is especially crowded during the cherry blossom season.

Meiji Jingu Shrine is a popular tourist hotspot close to Harajuku and Yoyogi Park. You can easily spend a few hours wandering around this area. It's particularly busy during national holidays and on New Year's.
Shibuya 109 is a women's fashion mall and a true landmark of the Shibuya area. Its brother, the 109 Men's mall, is located just on the other side of the street.
akeshita Street is a popular 'youth culture/fashion' shopping street located in Harajuku.

Deesigned by Rafael Viñoly Architects, this multi-purpose building is used as a concert hall, convention center and event space. Located in the Marunouchi business area close to Tokyo Station, concerts range from classical to jazz festival artists to established performers such as Yoko Ono. Convention center areas at the Tokyo International Forum are generally used for trade fairs and other events. The building also houses the Mitsuo Aida Museum (11F), a space dedicated to one of Japan's most famous calligraphers.
A large department store located in the upmarket and classy neighborhood of Ginza.
The Imperial Palace, located on the former site of Edo castle, is the current residence of the Imperial family.
Sukiyabashi Jiro Honten is a 3-star Michelin sushi restaurant located in Ginza.
Kabuki-za is the theater dedicated to Kabuki performances.
Yakitori is the classic Japanese dish of grilled meat or vegetable on a stick
This long alleyway is set in the upmarket area of Ebisu and is lined with many small taverns. It's a perfect place for a night of bar-hopping.
Sarutahiko Coffee is a popular local coffee shop just northeast of Ebisu station.
Sushi Ono is a 6-counter seat Edomae sushi (edo-era style) restaurant in Ebisu. The restaurant is operated by chef Jun Yoneyama under the name Sushi Sora on Sundays.
Ebisu Garden Place is a large open space in Ebisu often used for big events, movie premiers etc, and also contains a variety of shops and restaurants.
Ebisu Shrine, formerly known as Amatsu shrine, is located close to Ebisu station.
The Museum of Yebisu Beer is located in the district of Ebisu in Shibuya, Tokyo.
Sensoji Temple is a Buddhist Temple located at the end of Nakamise Road in Asakusa. It was built in 628, which makes it the oldest temple in Tokyo.

Kappabashi Street, or Kitchen Town is lined with shops that sell restaurant supply goods, dishes, pots, pans, cooking utensils and also stores that sell plastic and wax food samples, famously used by many restaurants in their show windows.
AI club is a bar/club with a focus on 80's soul music but with other generations of music as well. It is located right off of Kaminarimon street.
Asakusa Shrine is famous for its Sanja Matsuri Festival held in May.
Kaminarimon is the gateway to Senso-ji Temple, the largest temple in Asakusa.
Asakusa Ameya is a candy store offering traditional Japanese candies and lollipops.
The Imperial Palace, located on the former site of Edo castle, is the current residence of the Imperial family.
Nijubashi Bridge (literally "double bridge") is one of the most famous spots of the Imperial Palace.
Mitsubishi Ichigokan Museum, Tokyo, holds three feature exhibitions a year on modern art from the late 19th to early 20th centuries.

Chidorigafuchi is a moat located in the northwest of the Imperial Palace, and it is said the name comes from the moat's shape, which resembles plovers (chidori in Japanese). The moat is an historic site, and was constructed in the early Edo Period according to the expansion work of the castle, by damming the river. It used to be connected with Hanzo Moat.

A central hub for many JR train lines, this station also services many subway lines as well as the Shinkansen (bullet trains). It is also a vibrant and busy area for shopping, dining and gift purchases.
Sakuradamon was repaired in 1636. The Masugata (a cubic space before the main gate) of Sakuradamon is about 27 meters x 38 meters (15 ken X 21 ken), which is the largest among existing castle gates.

Yoyogi Park is one of the largest parks in central Tokyo and is located next to Harajuku Station and Meiji Shrine. It is a place where joggers, cyclists, music fans and picnickers gather on sunny days. It is especially crowded during the cherry blossom season.

Meiji Jingu Shrine is a popular tourist hotspot close to Harajuku and Yoyogi Park. You can easily spend a few hours wandering around this area. It's particularly busy during national holidays and on New Year's.
Takeshita Street is a popular 'youth culture/fashion' shopping street located in Harajuku.

Located in central Omotesando, this souvenir store carries many unique items such as ceramic-based lamps and traditional Japanese screens. Long considered one of Tokyo's better one-stop shops for cultural gifts, the Oriental Bazaar counts John Lennon as one of its more famous customers. The musician made an impromptu visit when the Beatles toured Japan in 1966.
Mandarake Complex is a 8-storey shop selling used mangas, figurines and video games.
Yodobashi is a chain of stores specialising in cameras, camera equipment, and other electronics and household goods.
http://www.curemaid.jp/
An upmarket mega-complex featuring shops, offices, restaurants, cafes, a museum and a cinema

Tokyo Midtown is a city within the city in the center of Tokyo's Roppongi district. Opened in 2007, the complex includes apartments, offices, shops, restaurants, museums, park space and a luxury hotel. In its center stands one of Tokyo's tallest buildings, the 248 meter tall Midtown Tower.

A leading exhibitor of contemporary art with a particular focus on Asia, this Tokyo museum has built a reputation for rigorous curation. Located on the 53rd floor of the Mori Hills Tower of the Roppongi Hills complex, exhibitions often include photography, architecture and design. Its annual Roppongi Crossing exhibition showcases the work of established and upcoming Japanese contemporary artists such as Takashi Murakami and Yoshimoto Nara. The Mori Musem of Art was designed by real estate developer Minoru Mori.

The huge, ultra-modern National Art Center, Tokyo, opened at the beginning of 2007. The National Art Center Tokyo is a short walk from Roppongi Hills. Designed by Kisho Kurokawa, the gleaming glass structure is Japan's largest exhibition space (see picture below). Dedicated to special exhibitions, it has no permanent collection of its own.

As a photojournalist, the camera is my partner to capture the most important moments. However, it doesn’t take a photojournalist to like cameras or taking photos. If you have an interest in cameras, photography, or both, Fujifilm Square is a place you’ll fall in love with. The location is convenient for tourists being located 5 minutes from Roppongi Station. It is also part of Tokyo Midtown surrounded by other attractions such as 21_21 Design Sight, the Suntory Museum of Art, the National Art Center, the Mori Art Museum, and Hinokicho Park.
Read more: http://www.japanvisitor.com/japan-city-guides/japan-museums/national-art-center#ixzz4DDTD1oYY

Odaiba Seaside Park is directly next to the Daisan Daiba (remains of the No. 3 Battery), and is surrounded by a peaceful bay. Visitors can enjoy playing on the sandy beach, windsurfing, or other pastimes. The park offers beautiful views of boats passing through the bay, the town on the opposite shore past the Rainbow Bridge, and the setting sun.
Hara Museum of Contemporary Art showcases a variety of permanent and temporary exhibitions throughout the year. Check out the website for their schedule.

Odaiba is a popular shopping and entertainment district on a man made island in Tokyo Bay. It originated as a set of small man made fort islands (daiba literally means "fort"), which were built towards the end of the Edo Period (1603-1868) to protect Tokyo against possible attacks from the sea and specifically in response to the gunboat diplomacy of Commodore Perry.
Venus Fort is a shopping mall/outlet complex located in Koto-ku. The interior of the shopping mall is designed to emulate the architecture of 17th and 18th century Europe.
Daikanransha is a 115-metre (377 ft) tall Ferris wheel located in Palette Town in Odaiba, Tokyo
Tokyo Joypolis is an indoors arcade/theme park, with rides and attractions ranging from rollercoasters to haunted houses to shooting and driving games.
